Award.AwardTitle: Single cell transcriptome analysis: a chemical approach for studying mammalian gene regulation
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes program is supporting the research of Professor Zhong of the University of Southern California. Professor Zhong will investigate the reprogramming mechanism of mammalian cells with single-cell transcriptome analysis. Although traditional cell lysate approaches provide significant quantities of RNA for analysis, the temporal and quantitative gene expression information is erased and averaged among all cells in the lysate. The "lost key" of gene regulatory relationships is to be found in single-cell transcriptomic analysis as opposed to the averaged cell lysate-techniques currently used in many traditional studies. The Zhong group will induce the expression of reprogramming factors (RFs) in cells to determine which genes are regulated by the induced-RFs at the single-cell level. This study will provide molecular information to dissect the genetic mechanism of reprogramming, deepen our understanding of cell fate decision, and demonstrate a novel chemical approach, single-cell transcriptome analysis, for chemical/cell biology.

The microfluidics/cell sorting/qPCR approach to single cell transcriptome analysis is expected to have broad scientific applications to problems at the chemistry/biology interface, far beyond the scope of this grant. As important, the project will contribute to education and training at the high school, undergraduate and graduate levels and involve efforts to broaden participation of under-represented minorities in modern chemical biology research. Plans for community outreach and "virtual lab" development also in place, and expected to widen the reach of this multi-disciplinary approach to research at the intersection of at the chemistry, nanoscale engineering and cell biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to infer gene regulation relationships from a collection of single-cell transcriptomes. The temporal and quantitative expression of genes is best preserved in a single-cell transcriptome. This study provides molecular information to dissect the genetic mechanism of reprogramming, deepens our understanding of cell fate decision, and demonstrates a novel chemical approach, single-cell transcriptome analysis, for molecular biology. During the life of the award, we published 14 peer-reviewed high impact manuscripts. These manuscripts not only shed lights into the molecular biology of cell fate decision and reprogramming, they also showed our commitment and efforts in undergraduate education as well as international collaborations.

The intellectual merit of this award including the knowledge and methods we developed and disseminated to the research community. The papers we published includes many coloration projects. These publications demonstrated that the intellectual merit of this award impacts the whole research community.  The broader impacts of this award is beyond the knowledge we disseminated with our publications and presentations at national and international meetings. This project provides research opportunities for several female undergraduate students, and high school students to participate in cutting edge molecular research at the PI’s laboratory in University of Southern California. With the research experience, these students have successfully entered professional school and colleges. This award impacts and changes the life of several female students by encouraging them to pursue a biomedical professional career. The success of these ungraduated and high school students depends on the research opportunity provided by this NSF award.

We have submitted more applications to NSF for the coming year. If we can successfully obtain another award, we will expand our effort and commitment to support more female and under-represented minority in molecular biology research. These research opportunities could significantly impact the career development of many undergraduate and high school students.
